notesStmt.note: A ballad in the form of a mock litany stairizing the army and Parliament.

The principal author of Mercurius melancholicus (1647-1649) was John Hackluyt; but rival periodicals with the same name sporadically appeared, one by John Crouch, another by Martin Parker and John Taylor. The anti-Presbyterian tone of this ballad denies Hackluyt's authorsip but is quite suitable to the verse of Crouch, Parker, or Taylor.
Reproduction of original in Thomason Collection, British Library.

div.p: THE ARMIES LETANIE, Imploring the Bleſsing of God on the preſent proceedings of the Armie.
By the Author of Mercurius Melancholicus.

div.head: The Armies Letany.
div.l: SInce that no wiſe man dares to ſay,
Put the Army if they liſt they may
Save us or bring us to decay:
Therefore let's pray.
From any Souldier whoſe intent
Is to ore-awe the Parliament,
And with his pay won't be content.
From Sutlers wives with faces tallow,
Who with their Trulls the Army follow,
From a Commander in chiefe, whoſe wit is ſhallow.
From a Souldier that ſweares, yet dares not fight,
But would plunder London if he might,
From meeting a partie late in the night.
From a Trooper that's mounted on a leane jade,
And of cutting throats has learnt the trade;
From digging with a ſword inſtead of a Spade.
Frim bed-cord Match and priming Powder,
From hearing the Drum ſpeak louder and louder,
From him that growes poor, and yet waxeth prouder.
From underminings and counterminings,
From Souldiers groanes and womens whinings,
From Booker and Lillies falſe divinings.
From Morter Pieces, and Hand Granadoes,
From Blockings up, and Barracadoes,
From diſcontented Reformadoes.
From Southwark-men, who are but Treachours,
From Countrey Fooles, and City Lechers,
From Sheriffs, Bailiffs, and Counter-catchers,
From buying of our peace with money,
From a falſe-hearted knave, whoſe words are honey,
From a Whores temptations who hath a hot—
From Harunies Pamphlets, and his fine Stories
Of Aſſes, Mules, and Dromedaries,
From Presbyterian Conſiſtories,
From a Buffe-coat blade that needs will preach,
From the doctrine the Anabaptiſts teach,
From a Committee-man, or any ſuch horſe-leach,
From good pretences, and bad intentions,
From hopes of plunder, and baſe inventions,
From Peters, when his dreames he mentions,
From being perſwaded out of our lives,
Our coine, goods, children, and our wives,
By thoſe who for our ruine ſtrives,
From a Winters Plague, and Summers Warre,
From ſleeping till we ruin'd are,
From thoſe that do delight to jarre,
From thoſe that now like Princes ſing,
Making themſelves, but marre the King,
From an Independent point, and a Presbyters ſting,
From laying claime to more then is ours,
From riding on the backs of the higher Powers,
From a brother that laughs and a ſiſter that lowres,
From an Agitator that ſtormes and frets,
And goodly Monſters each day begets,
From a Scotch miſt that devilliſhly wets.
From the Parliaments Climactricall yeare,
From the Sectaries hopes and the Cities feare,
From being forc'd againſt our conſciences to ſweare.
From1649. 49. and1652. If the world laſt ſo long. 52.
And thoſe Ills we then are like to view,
From old errours that are reviv'd anew
From a begging Scholler, or ſmall beere Poet,
Who can ſcarce write ſenſe yet the world muſt know it,
From him thats ſcabby and glories to ſhow it.
From ſetling all things by the ſword,
From thoſe that hate our Soveraigne Lord
Let England ſay with one accord,
THat it may pleaſe thy omnipotence,
Father of all excellence,
All jarres and ſtrifes to baniſh hence.
That it may pleaſe thee our Sir Thomas
May now at length fulfill his promiſe
In ſetling the King, who long hath been from us.
That it may pleaſe thee the Army may
Conſider what a prepoſterous way
It is to impeach thus every day.
That it may pleaſe thee to let them ſee
How hard thoſe Propoſitions be
Were lately ſhowne His Majeſtie.
That it may pleaſe thee, they may not rejoyce,
Nor yet with pride lift up their voice.
But to maintaine the truth make choice.
That it may pleaſe thee as hitherto
They have done, what thou bidſt them to do,
They the ſame temper ſtill may ſhow.
That it may pleaſe thee, we deſire,
The Citizens may never tire
To doe what the Army doth require.
That it may pleaſe thee, they may invent
New waies againſt the moneyes ſpent
They are to have, more may be lent.
That it may pleaſe thee with mild cheare
They may bow downe their backs to beare,
They will be wiſer ſure next yeare.
That it may pleaſe thee untill then,
My Lord Mayor and the Aldermen,
May re-inforce their Charter agen.
That it may pleaſe thee for to bleſſe
The Southwarkians with happineſſe,
For that they gave the Army acceſſe.
That it may pleaſe thee all Fleſh-flies,
With L • ke 〈◊〉 beards egregious lies,
May be abhorr'd by all that's wiſe.
Quaefumus te.
That it may pleaſe thee the Army may
No longer let the Tub-men pray
Extempore, and what they liſt to ſay.
That it may pleaſe thee they may declare
Thoſe Round-heads, whoſe deeds are not ſquare,
To be amongſt them unworthy are.
That it may pleaſe thee ſince 'tis in them
For to diſpoſe the Diadem,
With it they Charles his browes may hem.
That it may pleaſe thee, they may vie
With thoſe that would have Anarchie,
And ſurely ſettle Monarchie.
That it may pleaſe thee, the Army knowing
To what a height things now are growing,
May ſtop thoſe floods that in are flowing.
That it may pleaſe thee to perſwade the Scot
To be contented with his owne lot,
For he muſt loſe the footing he got.
That it may pleaſe thee, the good the Army intend
Us, in the receiving may not offend,
And ſo at once have birth and end.
That it may pleaſe thee the bloods of thoſe
Who ſome yeares paſt their lives did loſe,
'Twixt us and God mai'nt interpoſe.
That it may pleaſe thee we may thinke on
Our preſent dire confuſion,
Caus'd by the Devills deluſion.
That it may pleaſe thee ſhew the King
Thy ſtrange and wondrous managing
Doth make for him in every thing.
That it may pleaſe thee the world may ſee
Thy juſtice great and good to bee,
And what's the end of treacherie.
That it may pleaſe thee now at laſt,
The King may in his Throne be plac't,
And thoſe that hate him downe be caſt.
That it may pleaſe thee to let him be
Aſſured that Ariſtocracie
Will ever cauſe confederacie.
That it may pleaſe thee he ſo may raigne,
And his Sonnes when the Crowne they gaine,
England may ever in peace remaine.
So ſhall we be as once we were,
The Almighties love, the Nations feare,
And then we in each ſtreet ſhall heare
